title: 105_hr3170
content: Section 1 introduces a new section in the Internal Revenue Code, SEC. 1260, which deals with gains from constructive ownership transactions. The new section SEC. 1260 addresses gains from constructive ownership transactions, treating such gains as short-term capital gain if they exceed the net underlying long-term capital gain. The capital gain rate applicable is determined based on the respective rates that would have been applicable. The determination of capital gain rates under section 1(h) is based on the net underlying long-term capital gain. If gain is treated as short-term, interest charges may apply under section 6601. The taxpayer's tax for a taxable year may increase due to capital gains, with interest imposed under section 6601 for specific periods and underpayments from prior years if the gain was included in income during a constructive ownership transaction. The taxpayer may face an increase in tax for a taxable year due to capital gains, with interest imposed for specific periods and underpayments from prior years if the gain was included in income during a constructive ownership transaction. Any amount payable under this provision affects the deduction for interest paid or accrued in that taxable year. The taxpayer may face an increase in tax for a taxable year due to capital gains, with interest imposed for specific periods and underpayments from prior years if the gain was included in income during a constructive ownership transaction. Any amount payable under this provision affects the deduction for interest paid or accrued in that taxable year. No credits against the increase in tax shall be treated as tax imposed for determining the amount of any credit allowable under certain subparts or the tax imposed by section 55. The term 'financial position' refers to any position with respect to any stock or debt instrument. The taxpayer may face an increase in tax for a taxable year due to capital gains, with interest imposed for specific periods and underpayments from prior years if the gain was included in income during a constructive ownership transaction. The term 'financial position' refers to any position with respect to any stock, debt instrument, partnership interest, or investment trust interest. The taxpayer may face increased tax for a taxable year due to capital gains from a constructive ownership transaction involving futures, forward contracts, short sales, or options. This transaction includes holding a long position under a notional principal contract, entering into a futures contract, or being the grantor of a put. The taxpayer may face increased tax for a taxable year due to capital gains from transactions involving futures, forward contracts, short sales, or options. This includes entering into contracts, being the grantor of a put, or engaging in other transactions with similar effects. The taxpayer may face increased tax for a taxable year due to capital gains from transactions involving futures, forward contracts, short sales, or options. This includes entering into contracts, being the grantor of a put, or engaging in other transactions with similar effects such as equal strike prices or acquiring positions with the same effect. There is an exception for positions marked to market under any provision of the tax code. A person is considered to hold a long position under a notional principal contract if they have the right to receive the investment yield on the property for a specified period and are obligated to provide credit. The term 'forward contract' and 'related person' are defined in specific sections. 'Net Underlying Long-Term Capital Gain' is determined for tax purposes. The term 'related person' is defined in section 1259(c)(4). 'Net Underlying Long-Term Capital Gain' is the aggregate net capital gain in a constructive ownership transaction. The net underlying long-term capital gain is determined based on deemed ownership and clear evidence. Taxpayers can elect to apply this subsection. If a taxpayer elects to have this subsection apply, they shall recognize gain or loss on any open constructive ownership transaction as if the financial position were sold for its fair market value. The taxpayer must recognize gain or loss on any open constructive ownership transaction at the close of the taxable year as if the financial position were sold for its fair market value. Any gain or loss should be taken into account for that taxable year, with proper adjustments made for subsequent realized gains or losses. Any gain or loss from a constructive ownership transaction is treated as ordinary income or loss. If gain or loss is recognized before the end of the taxable year, it should be accounted for accordingly. Any gain or loss from a constructive ownership transaction is treated as ordinary income or loss, and can be recognized before the end of the taxable year without the need for the Secretary's consent. An election can be made without the Secretary's consent and applies to the current and future taxable years unless revoked. The Secretary will prescribe necessary regulations for this section. The amendments made by this section apply to gain recognized after the date of the enactment of this Act.
